desc: Currently, I design full-stack news visualizations at South China Morning Post Graphics in Hong Kong.
label: background

desc: My journey has also included leading creative production at the Global-Comm Lab of China News Service and working as a graphics reporter and product manager at Xinhua Media Creatives.
label: background

desc: Each role taught me how to adapt, innovate, and collaborate across disciplines and cultures.
label: background

desc: I thrive at the intersection of creativity and technology. I'm skilled in Adobe,Blender, Tableau, and Figma,
label: skill

desc: building and interactive experiences with d3.js, GSAP, and three.js. I also embrace AIGC creativity, exploring new ways to co-create with technology.
label: skill

desc: With a Ph.D. in Communication, my work is grounded in research and reflection—studying how visual narratives inform, persuade, and resonate.
label: researchBk

desc: I also care deeply about teaching, mentoring the next generation of data storytellers to think critically, design boldly, and experiment fearlessly.
label: researchBk

title: Bremer, N., & Wu, S. (2021). Data Sketches: A journey of imagination, exploration, and beautiful data visualizations.
Decisions in News Visualization: How News Visualization Teams Employ a Shared Mental Model
desc: This study aims to investigate the shared mindsets a team of professionals relies on to make collaborative production decisions, i.e., the shared mental model guiding professionals' news visualization production. A shared mental model is the shared cognitive structure held by all individual members of a team that helps them make sense of their tasks.

title: Analyzing Dorian Twitter Data to Understand How Hurricane Risk Assessments Change as Threats Unfold
desc: The results showed that professional accounts are more likely to post original content than share, among which most of the organizational accounts (including forecasters, emergency managements, and news outlets) post in regular intervals with a fixed message format and a neutral opinion while professional individual accounts (e.g. meteorologist, broadcasters) post with no  observable temporal regulation,  variable forms, and  sentiments. However,  the forecaster accounts  are less engaged than  the mediator accounts  (i.e. news outlets and professional individual account holders). The study also revealed that under the hurricane risk context, those willing to share information rely more on post timing and expertise of post creators, rather than message type and sentiment.

title: Design guidelines for hurricane risk forecast to non-expert users
desc: Hurricane forecast graphics, such as the cone of uncertainty and the hurricane threat impacts graphics, are provided to assist the general public in assessing their risk and in making protective action decisions for an approaching storm. Many researchers have demonstrated that hurricane forecast graphics are often misinterpreted by the general public. Few studies, however, have investigated the impact of design elements of these graphics on interpretations of hurricane risk communication for non-expert users. This study provides design guidelines for improving hurricane risks forecast products based on a literature review.

title: Design Guidelines for Immersive Dashboards
desc: Immersive dashboards facilitate the presentation of large-scale complex data while offering natural interaction and real-time interactivity supporting immediate use. Few studies, however, have investigated the use of immersive dashboards to improve the visualization and analysis of abstract data. This study provides a systematic review of the literature on designing immersive dashboards for abstract data visualization and analytics. Twenty publications met the inclusion criteria. This review identifies guidelines for improving immersive dashboard design.

title: Design suggestions of the hurricane threat impact graphics (summary of an investigation)
Unfolding the Decision-Making Dynamics of News Visualization Production in China
desc: A grounded analysis drawing on 15 in-depth interviews with professionals reveals the dynamics of source selection, interpretation, and presentation in news visualization production. It also shows that news visualization stories result from the debating and tradeoffs between the "western norms" and the organization's expectations, audiences' preferences, news commercialization, and macro environment in China.

title: Data journalism in China (Interviewed by Kontinentalist)
